The resolution of the outage occurred in the evening of this date, marking the end of the disruption that began early Monday morning.
Reference to a prior AWS outage in 2023, highlighting recurring vulnerability in cloud infrastructure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage began at approximately 3:11 a.m. Eastern time and lasted through the evening, with full recovery reported by 6 p.m. Eastern time.

keyTakeAways: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a major outage that disrupted internet services globally, affecting social media, gaming, financial platforms, and education tools.
The outage originated in AWS’s US-EAST-1 region and was traced to issues in the domain name system (DNS), which converts web addresses to IP addresses.
Services such as Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, Coinbase, Signal, Amazon Ring and Alexa, and Canvas were impacted.
The disruption affected over 2,500 companies as reported by DownDetector, with more than 11 million users experiencing issues.

Educational platforms like Canvas, used by 50% of college and university students in North America, including Ivy League schools, were disrupted, impacting students’ ability to submit assignments and access materials.
Cybersecurity experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess noted that such outages are typically due to technical failures, not cyberattacks, and are usually resolved within hours.
This incident highlights the world’s growing dependence on a small number of technology companies to maintain internet infrastructure, making the system vulnerable to cascading failures.
Amazon acknowledged the issue, reported recovery progress, and confirmed that services returned to normal by 6 p.m. Eastern time.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a significant cloud outage that began around 3:11 a.m. Eastern time on October 20, 2025, affecting a wide range of online services including social media, gaming, financial platforms, streaming, and education tools. The root cause was traced to issues in AWS’s domain name system (DNS), which disrupted the ability of websites to load properly. More than 2,500 companies reported outages, with over 11 million users impacted. Services including Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, Coinbase, Signal, Amazon Ring, Alexa, and Canvas were affected. Educational institutions such as the University of California, Riverside, and Ohio State University reported students unable to access coursework or submit assignments. Amazon confirmed recovery by 6 p.m. Eastern time, with experts noting that such outages are typically due to technical failures, not cyberattacks, and are usually resolved within hours. This incident underscores the growing vulnerability of internet infrastructure, as society increasingly depends on a small number of cloud providers for critical online functions.
title: Amazon Cloud Outage Exposes Internet’s Vulnerable Backbone
